body:
Hello all, 
For those who don't have much experience making videos and are looking for some advise, please check out our Shawn's (Shawn helps us with technical stuff) recommendation on the videos tab if you haven't already does so.  
https://www.ima.umn.edu/topology/videos/contribute

Also, Matthew Wright whose videos are available on the Youtube channel has provided us with insights into how creates his vidoes: 

"
I start making my videos by planning what I wanted to say and creating slides in PowerPoint. Of course, other presentation software could be used; I use PowerPoint for its drawing and animation tools.

After preparing my slides, I use the free software ActivePresenter to record a video of my presentation. ActivePresenter is able to capture the slides on my computer screen and audio as I narrate the slides; other similar software is available. For high-quality audio, I use a desktop microphone (I have a Blu Snowball mic) rather than the built-in mic on my laptop. I then use ActivePresenter to for minor video editing, checking for mistakes and correcting any I
seed.title: New to making videos?

body:
Hello everyone,
As many of you know, we have recently started a Youtube channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC-_buHgDs25DacoSEPrfNgQ ( Don't forget to subscribe) for this network. This channel will have two primary purposes:
1. To supplement our seminar series in helping our community members keep up with research of other members.
2. To help popularize TDA among people outside our community.
3. To help everyone advertise their work via short videos.

If anyone has suggestions for specific topics you would like covered in a video, please suggest them right here in this Forum.  Feel free to also post links to videos that you have either made or found to be informative.

If you would like to contact us directly, please send email me (Harish, harishkumar.ch@gmail.com) or Don (don.r.sheehy@gmail.com).  We are happy to upload or link your existing videos to this new YouTube channel.

Once we have a critical mass of videos, we will be more aggressive in advertising the channel in many venues.
seed.title: Vidoes

body:
** Apologies for cross-postings. Please send to interested colleagues and students. **

                  First Call for Papers and Participation FWCG 2015
                 The 25th Fall Workshop on Computational Geometry
                       State University of New York at Buffalo
                                         Oct 23 - 24, 2015
                                   info:  http://www.cse.buffalo.edu/fwcg2015                                       
                                      Registration: FREE
                     Deadline for submissions: September 25, 2015

Conference Scope:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The aim of this workshop is to bring together students and researchers
from academia and industry, to stimulate collaboration on problems of
common interest arising in geometric computations. Topics to be covered
include computational geometry and related topics, e.g.,

    * Algorithmic methods in geometry and topology
    * Sensor networks and network technologies
    * I/O-scalable geometric algorithms
seed.title: Call for Papers: The 25th Fall Workshop on Computational Geometry

body:
I have been asked this question recently, and I don't think I have a good answer: what are the journals to submit results in computational topology to?

I am aware of 
Homology, Homotopy and Algebra
Foundations of Computational Mathematics
Discrete and Computational Geometry
Computational Geometry: Theory and Applications
seed.title: Journals for Computational Topology

body:
Hi there, 
I was wondering if it is possible to find the area underneath the persistence landscape from 0 to some time t, where t will vary depending on the contour (and the length of the betti barcode) using R? Is there a function that can help me to perform this integral?
Thanks!
seed.title: Area under Persistence Landscapes (integral)

body:
Hi there, 
I was hoping someone could help explain to me what exactly this means:
Given persistence landscapes with functions lambda1(t), ....lambdak(t), where k =15, what does it mean to do SVM on concatenated lambdas? I don't really understand this concept, and would like to have some clarity. 
Thanks!
seed.title: SVM on Concatenated Lambdas

body:
Generally, I want to know what are the limits of using some of the software packages out there.  But, let's be specific:

Suppose we have n points sampled in R^3, taken i.i.d. from the uniform distribution over a large compact domain.  Now, let's compute the persistence diagram for some standard filtered complex (Rips, cech, alpha, ... whichever you choose).

The question: how big can n be if you are using, say, a typical (new-ish) laptop?  (Does it depend on the package you are using?)
seed.title: Persistence in Big Data?  How Big?

body:
Hi there, I was wondering if it is possible to do SVM with linear kernel applied to persistence landscapes? I'm not sure how to go about doing this....and if R can do it.?
Thanks!
seed.title: SVM & R

body:
The proposed method by Carlsson and his group which is called MAPPER can be used to reduce high dimensional datasets into simplicial complexes with far fewer points which can capture topological and geometric information at a specified resolution. 
I am wondering if the Mapper algorithm has been written in MATLAB or not, if so where I can find it. This was my question to Dr. Mikael Vejdemo-Johansson, he guid me to Gurjeet Singh work as JavaPlex code see "  http://javaplex.googlecode.com/svn-history/r150/trunk/src/matlab/hom_messy/mapper.m ".
seed.title: Mapper Algorithm
What are some good TDA survey articles?

body: I am aware that R package TDA can compute Wasserstein distance between persistence diagrams, but I was wondering if there was a way for the program to calculate distances between persistence landscapes?
seed.title: Distance between Persistence Landscapes

body:
The field of computational topology has grown rapidly over the past few years, so Brittany Fasy and I have set up a listserv that we would like to invite you to join (both men and women are encouraged to join).  We will use this listserv to share opportunities, to remind each other of approaching deadlines, as well as a means to reach out to a supporting community.  

If you are interested in joining, please send a blank email to: 
WinCompTop+subscribe@googlegroups.com
An automated response will prompt you to confirm your request.  After confirming, your request must be approved by a group admin (we will, of course, approve you).  If you have any trouble signing up, do not hesitate to reach out.
seed.title: Women in Computational Topology

body:
2015-08-17 to 2015-08-28
University of Victoria

This conference aims to bring together applied topologists and spatial statisticians that are curious about each-other's work.  We anticipate having two relatively-distinct groups: 1) topologists that have been working with applied algebraic-topological tools like persistent homology, 2) statisticians working in the area of high-dimensional data analysis, and researchers from fields that involve large data problems.  We aim to have as many general-interest talks as possible but as talks get more technical and special-interest we might see some parallel sessions aimed towards one particular audience. The other principal aspect of the conference is the first week we will have talks aimed primarily at a graduate student audience, covering the most basic topics in algebraic topology, persistent homology, and the basics of the fields people are applying these topics to, such as economics, brain imaging and genomics.
seed.title: Applied Topology and High-Dimensional Data Analysis meeting in Victoria

body:
2015-09-14 to 2015-09-18
Berlin, Germany

Shape Up 2015

Exercises in Materials Geometry and Topology

The conference will be an interdisciplinary discussion meeting on
patterns and geometry, and their role in biological and synthetic
microstructured materials and tissue.. We invite contributions
from biology, chemistry, materials science, mathematics, physics
and related fields addressing the genesis, properties and function
of complex nano-scale geometries, as well as underlying geometric
and topological concepts for the study of complex structure and shape..

The key areas of interest include:

* Geometric and topological concepts in soft condensed matter
* Characterization of structure and function
* Topological data analysis and image reconstruction
seed.title: Shape Up 2015: Exercises in Materials Geometry and Topology

body: At our small, undergraduate institution, it is always a struggle to get enough students to offer our introductory topology course.  With the growth of computational topology and topological data analysis, it has occurred to us that incorporating applications into our topology course might make it more attractive to students.  If anyone has already made or is planning such a modification to a first undergraduate topology course, my colleagues and I would be very interested in hearing about it.
seed.title: Applications in undergraduate topology course
